items.content:
Onderwerp Dream poetry
Schooltype VO (havo/vwo)
Doelgroep Klas 3/4
Vakgebieden Engels
Aantal personen 4 leerlingen
Totale tijd 3 tot 5 klokuren

Welcome to this webquest about poetry! Please click the other tabs to enter the world of interesting lines on dreams.

Ladies and gentlemen!

When you were a toddler, you listened to lullabies. When you were a child, you learned funny songs by heart. Now, it's time to get amused by serious poems. This world doesn't end with the objective limits, our imagination can reach much further until it meets 'another sky' as Emily Dickinson calls it in one of her poems.

This webquest helps you to find your way in the land of poetry. Which poems do you like? Are there any poems that fit your feelings? And how about writing your own poetry? You will discover that poetry is really not just for lonely grandma's, but that there is actually poetry in every corner of the world. Did you know that popstars are in fact simply interpreters of poetry!?!

Expressing your own feelings can be a perfect way of solving the chaos in your head. And playing with words can be very funny too!

In short: Enjoy this webquest!!

After finishing this webquest, you will be acquainted with different types of poems and you will know what kind of poetry you like best. Why do you think these poems so appalling? Furthermore, you have to be able to talk about your ideas with your classmates, so think about arguments for your point of view.

To reach these goals, you have to do the exercises in the file folder 'Werkwijze'. There you can find six sections wich cover several questions. Answer these questions and collect your answers in a Word-document. You can do this in Dutch. Use headings to make your paper look well-structured.

Do section A-D and F on your own. Section E is a group task: you have to discuss section D with three classmates.You have got four lessons to work through the sections.

Use the links in the file folder 'Bronnen'. You had better not use other websites: if you do there is a risk of getting lost at the world wide web ;-) Besides, the listed websites are comprehensible in that they have an index of themes (except for the www.azlyrics.com), so it will be very easy to find a poem on the subject you are looking for.

Hand in your paper in the week after the last lesson you worked at the project in class.

LESSON 1

A. What do you think?

  1. What do you think of poems? Do you like them? Why or why not?
  2. What are the characteristics of a poem, in your (!) opinion? You should think of using rhyme or free verse, short/long lines, concrete/abstract topics, etc. You can find some links at the 'Bronnen'-page which can help you create your own definition of poetry. You should not depend on the information on the websites and in the file: depend on your own thoughts.

B. Explaining other people's Dreams

  1. Ask your teacher for the handout 'Explaining other people's Dreams' (if you don't have it yet!) and read the poems. What are the poets dreaming of? Why do you think so?
  2. List these five poems in order of quality, with the best first.
  3. What does make each poem so good or bad? Illustrate your opinion with a sentence or words from the poem.

LESSON 2 & 3

C. Your personal dreams explained by others

  1. People dream about frightening ánd beautiful things, about the past, about the future, etc. What exactly do you dream of? What kind of emotions do you feel in your dreams?
  2. Search the internet to find a poem that gives expression to your dream.
  3. Explain, per sentence, what the poem says according to you. If metaphors are used, what ideas does the poet compare to each other? What are the similarities between these ideas?
  4. What do you think of the language use in the poem? Does it meet your feelings or do you think the imagery too far-fetched?

D. Your personal poem on your own dream

Write your own poem on one of your dreams. Use your own criteria in writing this poem. You should not feel obliged to use any poetic phenomena like rhyme in this poem.

LESSON 4

E. Your personal poem explained by others

In groups of four, discuss the poems you made. Pass your poem to the person at your right hand.

First, think about an interpretation of your neighbour's poem. What is his/her dream about? What kind of language does he/she use? Why does he/she use this particular kind of language? How does he feel about his/her dreams? Do you like the poem?

Second, present your interpretation of the poem you studied to your groupmates. Do they agree with your interpretation? What does the writer think about it?

F. Reflection

  1. After you have read all this poetry, what do you think of poems? Did your opinion change while studying them?
  2. What did you learn from the poems you have read? Were they in any way useful to you? Are you going to read more poetry for yourself?
  3. Did you like writing your own poem? Why or why not?
  4. Were you surprised at your classmates' reaction at your poem?

Section A: Literary terms

  • http://www.collegenet.nl/studiemateriaal/index.php?categorie=poezie
  • www.majaeger.de/site/school/files/Poetry.doc

Section C: Websites with lots of poems!

  • http://www.poets.org/page.php/prmID/200
  • http://www.poetseers.org/themes
  • http://www.poemhunter.com/poems/
  • http://www.azlyrics.com/

Online dictionary:

  • www.vertalen.nu
  • www.interglot.com

Your mark depends on the following criteria:

  • Does your paper look proper? (max. 5 points)
  • Did you answer all the questions? (max. 5 points)
  • Did you defend your answers convincingly? (max. 10 points)
  • Did you use any creativity while writing your own poem? (max. 10 points)
  • How well did you participate in the discussion? (max. 10 points)

Total amount of points / 40 = final mark

Maybe this was the first time you read any poetry since your last learned-by-heart song at primary school. Perhaps you had never thought about popsongs as a form of poetry. Possibly you thought that you would never do an attempt to read any boring lines again after you had to read a totally incomprehensible poem. This webquest took you by the hand to (re)discover poems.

After your favourite poem was found, you were asked to write your own one. If you had never done anything like creative writing before, you may have been surprised by the vast opportunity of expressing your feelings in such a pleasant way. By discussing your poem and that of your classmates, you got acquainted with another aspect of their character, so that your friendship may have been deepened.

Now you know what poetry is, don't stop the temptation to read further. There is an enormous amount of poetry online. Besides, bookshops have interesting assortments of poem collections.

If you liked writing your own poem, don't hesitate to write more in the future. It can be very funny and helpful to you. According to a certain 'Lord Acton', it can even be instructive. His advise: "Learn as much by writing as by reading."

Doelgroep:

Deze opdracht is geschikt voor de derde klas van het voortgezet onderwijs. Het niveau van het Engels is dan geschikt voor het begrijpen van de opdrachten. Doe deze opdracht niet in een klas zonder 'veilige sfeer': dit zal de groepsdiscussie waarin eigen ervaringen/emoties centraal staan niet ten goede komen.

Doel:

Het doel van de opdracht is leerlingen enthousiast te maken voor poëzie. Het is dus een verkennende opdracht, zonder veel diepgang in analytische zin. Gedichtanalyse kan het enthousiasme van leerlingen in de eerste drie leerjaren van het VO in de kiem smoren doordat dit als saai wordt ervaren. Daarom is deze webquest gebaseerd op een affectieve benadering van poëzie. Voor de geïnteresseerde leerling is er in Section 1 de mogelijkheid om zich te verdiepen in poëzie-technische termen.

Thema:

Het thema 'Dromen' is een breed thema dat dicht bij de leerlingen staat, zodat het iedere individuele leerling kan aanspreken. In de hand-out zijn vijf gedichten opgenomen die stuk voor stuk over dromen gaan, maar die elk een eigen stijl en onderwerp hebben. Hoewel niet elke leerling elk gedicht even interessant zal vinden, zal er door het gevarieerde aanbod vast en zeker één tussen zitten die hem of haar aanspreekt.

Opbouw

De webquest is zo samengesteld dat de leerling van zijn zakelijke opvattingen naar zijn emotionele ervaringen toewerkt:

  • Section A: Vaststellen van eigen opvatting over het fenomeen poëzie.
  • Section B: Aan de slag met dromen van andere mensen: wat beschrijven zij?
  • Section C: De eigen dromen worden erbij gehaald: in welk gedicht herken je je eigen droom?
  • Section D: De eigen creativiteit gaat aan de slag met de eigen dromen. Hoe verwoord je je eigen gedachten in een gedicht?
  • Section E: Het eigen werk wordt gepresenteerd aan de groepsgenoten en de leerlingen gaan erover in discussie.
  • Section F: Reflectie op het project.

Planning:

Les 1: Introductie, Sections A&B

Les 2-3: Section C&D

Les 4: Section E&F

Voorbereiding:

  • 'Explaining other people's dreams' (kleine reader met de gedichten voor Section B) uitdelen.
  • Leerlingen in groepjes van 4 verdelen voor de discussie in Section E (de rest van de webquest bestaat uit individuele opdrachten!)
